awd_titl_txt: Fundamentals of Anhydrous Proton Transport on the Surface of Functionalized Graphane
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project involves studying the transport of charge, in the form of protons, at interfaces and surfaces.  This process is important for a wide range of technologies, including fuel cells and biological membranes, all of which contain membranes that transport protons.  Currently used membranes for fuel cells require a high degree of hydration to operate and therefore are limited to operating at low temperatures.  Operation at higher temperatures causes the membranes to dry out and lose their ability to conduct charge. Thus, it is important for fuel cell technologies to develop such membranes that can operate dry and at higher temperatures. In this project, new materials are being developed that can transport protons while in a dehydrated state.  Computational modeling is being used to design, test and optimize the materials. 

This research project involves (i) elucidation of proton hopping mechanisms and barriers on in 1-d chains and on 2-d functionalized surfaces, (ii) insight into how proton-proton interactions change proton transport mechanisms, (iii) the development of an efficient but accurate empirical multi-state, multi-configurational molecular simulation framework for simulating proton transport in heterogeneous environments, and (iv) development of high performance computing algorithms for implementing highly-parallel simulations on core and graphical processing units.  The researchers are developing a multi-state, multi-configurational reactive molecular simulation framework for studying anhydrous proton exchange membranes and are developing a novel high performance computing software framework for efficient simulations on current and as well as emerging computing architectures. The group is also pursuing outreach activities focused on recruiting underrepresented undergraduate students from Howard University to participate in summer research on this project and enrolling the students in the University of Pittsburgh's Pre-Ph.D. program to prepare them for graduate school and careers in research.

por.por_cntn:
A key component of hydrogen fuel cells is the proton conducting membrane. Current membrane materials used in commercial fuel cells are not intrinsic proton conductors. They rely on the presence of water in order to conduct protons. This limits the operating temperature and humidity conditions of the fuel cell and adds cost and complexity to the fuel cell through requiring water management hardware. Membrane materials capable of conducting protons without water will improve reliability and reduce the cost of fuel cells. We have designed and evaluated two new materials that can conduct protons without water through the use of atomistic computer simulations. We have developed advanced machine learning potentials that we used to evaluate proton conduction. We have demonstrated that these deep-learning potentials are able to simulate these materials with almost the same accuracy as quantum mechanics methods, but thousands of times faster than the quantum mechanics simulations. We developed a technique for combining classical simulations and deep-learning potentials in a hybrid simulation formalism. This formalism has the advantage of being able to use widely-available classical potentials for simulating interaction of molecules with porous solids and other materials, so long as no bond-breaking and bond-forming events are required for modeling the molecules. Our simulations were used to identify the mechanisms for separation of oxygen isotopes through adsorption at cryogenic temperatures.

This research involved undergraduate students from underrepresented groups, including a historically black college.  The outcome of the undergraduate research included preparing several of the students for graduate school. The broader aspects of this work include the potential to reduce the cost and improve the reliability of hydrogen fuel cells. Fuels cells have the potential to reduce greenhouse gas emissions through decarbonization of the transportation sector.
